I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
The Olympic Games were founded on high ideals that politics could be set aside to clear the field for athletic competition.
The Olympic charter expressly opposes the mixture of politics and sport.

Yet, of course, the games have been used to make political points over and over again: By nations, the Nazi Olympics in 1936 Berlin and reciprocal Cold War boycotts in Moscow and Los Angeles in the 1980s; by groups, including the terrorists who murdered Israeli athletes at Munich; and by any number of individuals.
The upcoming Summer Olympics in Beijing are no exception.
Steven Spielberg quit his artistic adviser to the opening and closing ceremonies because of his views on China's role in Sudan's Darfur province.

A Dutch lawmaker suggested that a boycott of the opening ceremonies be staged to protest China's record on human rights and the masks that some athletes may wear to protect their lungs could also be seen as a statement on the environment.
Today, we'll take a look back at the intersection of politics and sports in the Olympic Games and look ahead to the role of reform and protest at this summer's games.
We want to hear from athletes and from fans.
Should politics play a role in the Olympic Games?
Have you been moved by protest at past games?

(Reading) For years they have come for you - awkward-size envelopes labeled POR AVION, affixed with multiple oversized stamps honoring men from another country.
Monthly, you would peel eggshell pages, the white onionskin paper telling details - Kiki's first steps, your mother's death, dates approximated by the postmarks.
Sometimes with pictures - mute black-and-whites, poor photos of poor cousins I would handle looking for my resemblance in the foreign image of an ear, an eyebrow or a nose.

When possible, you would parcel a few pounds of your desperation in discreet brown packages - medicines, bubblegum, our family's photos, a few yards of taffeta needed for a Quinces gown - always waiting for your letters, always.
Your anxieties locked in the crumbling mosaic of memories you face, like the coral face of a fountain goddess, your stone mouth and eyes in a garden of exile.
